newsitem.title: USA: EMC offers software to manage,retrieve stored data.
newsitem.headline: EMC offers software to manage,retrieve stored data.

text.p: EMC Corp filling a critical hole in its product line, will unveil Monday two software products that make it easier for companies to manage and retrieve information stored on their mainframe computers.
EMC, a maker of big disk-drive systems, also will announce the backing of database software publisher Oracle Corp and computer maker Hewlett-Packard Co.
The new storage products are an answer to customers' requests for easier access to data stored on EMC disk-drive systems, said Jim Rothnie, senior vice president of marketing.
They also will be a boost to EMC's small but profitable software business, analysts said.
"It's an important one for them," said Gary Helmig, a SoundView Financial Group analyst.
EMC will unveil DataReach, a program that takes information stored in a mainframe's database and converts it into a format that can be read by popular database systems for desktop computer networks.
The program helps speed up the operation of the mainframe and makes it easier for PC users to access information.
DataReach will sell for about $100,000, EMC executives said.

EMC also will unveil TimeFinder, a program that takes a snapshot of the information zipping through a mainframe or corporate network and makes it easier for technicians to perform tasks such as back-ups.
"No products like these exist anywhere in the world today," Rothnie said. "We were driven to develop these capabilities because of requests from our customers."
EMC, based in Hopkinton, Mass., will showcase the products in San Francisco.
Until recent years, EMC specialized in making giant disk-drive systems that stored information for mainframe computers, the computing workhorses of big companies.
A couple of years ago, the company began making storage systems for networks based on the Unix standard, as well.
Rothnie said the new software products should help EMC gain more customers as more companies use a mixture of mainframes and Unix networks.
